ranked_diseases.explanation: Patient presents with classic Fanconi anemia features including pancytopenia, short stature, cafe-au-lait spots, radial ray defects (absent thumb and radius), and positive chromosomal breakage test. Group A is the most common complementation group (60-70% of cases).

All reference cases were diagnosed with FA group C. Patient shares identical phenotypic features including hematologic abnormalities, skeletal defects, and chromosomal instability. Group C accounts for ~10% of FA cases.
Presents with typical FA features. Group D2 is less common but shows similar clinical manifestations including bone marrow failure, radial ray anomalies, and chromosomal fragility.
Compatible with FA diagnosis based on hematologic findings and congenital anomalies. Group G is rare but presents with similar phenotype including skeletal abnormalities and pancytopenia.
Features absent radius and thrombocytopenia, but TAR syndrome typically spares the thumb. The presence of absent thumb, pancytopenia, and positive chromosomal breakage test makes FA more likely.
Can present with anemia, short stature, and thumb anomalies. However, typically shows isolated red cell aplasia rather than pancytopenia, and lacks chromosomal fragility seen in this patient.
